Pediatric Diseases

Pediatric Direct Methods 【Song Dynasty, Qian Yi】

Treatment of Internal and External Pediatric Diseases

In cases of internal pediatric diseases, symptoms include swollen eyes, abdominal distension, diarrhea with greenish-white stools, and gradually becoming emaciated; for external diseases, there may be redness and sores under the nose, frequent rubbing of the nose and ears, or sores on the limbs. For nasal sores, use Orchid Fragrance Powder; for general sores, use White Powder.

For liver diseases (also called tendinous diseases), symptoms are white membranes covering the eyes, possible bloody diarrhea, and emaciation; treat with Rehmannia Pills.

For heart diseases, symptoms include a yellow face with red cheeks and a robust, feverish body; treat with Calming Spirit Pills.

For spleen diseases (also known as corpulent diseases), symptoms encompass a yellow, emaciated body with dry skin and sores; abdominal distension with a craving for soil; treat with Beneficial Yellow Powder.

For kidney diseases (also known as osseous diseases), symptoms include emaciated limbs, widespread sores and scabs, and a preference for sleeping in damp places; treat with Rehmannia Pills.

For lung diseases (also called qi diseases), symptoms include wheezing, coughing, shortness of breath, and sores in the mouth and nose; treat with Beneficial Yellow Powder.[1p]
If suffering from tidal fever, one should first nourish the liver and then purge the heart. If one rashly uses drugs like natron and yellow sulfur, it can be harmful. If afflicted with lumps, one should dissolve them; if mistakenly treated with seeds or borax, it can lead to deterioration. Mismanagement of cold damage can also lead to sores. In the case of initial illness manifesting as a hot sore, use Huang Lian Pills; for chronic illness manifesting as a cold sore, use Mu Xiang Pills; for a combination of hot and cold symptoms, use Ru Sheng Pills; if fluids are deficient, use Bai Zhu Powder. All these conditions result from severe illness damaging the spleen and stomach, leading to the loss of bodily fluids. Therefore, strengthening the spleen and stomach should be the priority, and treatment should be applied early to prevent deterioration.

Note: Regarding sore conditions, these may arise from early weaning, excessive consumption of sweets and rich foods, or consuming harsh medications that significantly deplete bodily fluids, resulting in excessive虚火. They may also stem from innate constitution or the mother's rich diet and emotional influences, all of which require internal adjustment.

If the mouth and tongue are ulcerated, the body is feverish, the cheeks and lips are red, or there is swelling and pain, abdominal discomfort, heat in the palms, dryness in the throat, thirst for water, red urine, nocturnal sweating, and nervousness, this indicates inner and outer conditions of the heart. Use An Shen Pills as main treatment.

If sores appear on the nose, the eyes are red and inflamed, limbs resemble scabs, there are abscesses in front and behind the ears, the neck is swollen, there are lumps in the armpits, or small swellings in the lower abdomen, groin, and scrotum, with urination issues (either discolored or white discharge), nail-biting, head shaking, squinting, a whitish membrane covering the eyes causing light sensitivity and fear of sunlight, bloating with visible veins, and dry mouth with bloody discharge, this indicates inner and outer conditions of the liver. Use Di Huang and Lu Hui Pills as main treatment.[2p]
If the head does not grow hair, or has sore scabs, or the hair is tufted, or if the mouth and tongue are red and ulcerated, accompanied by abdominal pain, vomiting, inability to digest milk and food, dry mouth with a craving for dirt, foul-smelling diarrhea, cloudy urine, or if one has dimmed vision and drowsiness, and dislikes the sound of wood, this indicates an internal and external condition of the spleen channel, to be treated with the Fat Child Pill.

If sores form on the nose, there is difficulty in the throat, swollen neck, tooth pain, coughing with alternating chills and fevers, wrinkled skin, shortness of breath, itchy nose with discharge, nosebleeds, and yellowish eyes, this signifies an internal and external condition of the lung channel, to be treated with the Rehmannia Lung Cleansing Decoction.

If there is heat in the brain with phlegm, cold extremities, alternating chills and fevers, watery diarrhea with abdominal pain, foul breath and thirst, ulcerated gums, blackened nails and dark complexion, sores on the body or ears with discharge, or if food is expelled, this reflects an internal and external condition of the kidney channel, to be treated with the Rehmannia Pill.

In cases of heat attacking upwards, or when toxins from pox rise, the situation can develop rapidly, referred to as "running horse dysentery," requiring urgent application of realgar powder and toad pills. If mild, it leads to decaying gums and painful, swollen lips, which can be treated; if severe, gums may erode completely and submandibular and cheek areas may rot, which is untreatable.

Traditionally, it is said there are twelve signs of unjust dysentery.

Original source by Ni Weide, Ming Dynasty.[3p]
The Disease Caused by Deep Deficiency

The harm from deep deficiency arises when the protective qi is weak, allowing coldness to invade; when the vital qi is diminished, leading to injuries from food and drink; and when external factors invade and cause internal damage, resulting in this condition. Parents, due to their pure yang nature, do not wear heavy clothing in deep winter; due to their aversion to cold winds, they do not shed their garments even in the height of summer. Some parents, with their frequent hunger, force-feed after nursing; others, when thirsty, give more liquid after nursing. There are foolish parents who do not discern the effects of cold, heat, food, and drink, hence they do not provide warmth when it is cold, cannot cool down when it is hot, do not quench thirst with drinks, and do not feed adequately when hungry. The child remains silent, holding on to the disease without being able to express it, thus allowing external factors to invade and internal damage to accumulate gradually, leading to the development of deficiency.

Symptoms may include thirst with easy hunger, the ability to eat yet losing weight, abdominal distension with diarrhea, and a whistling sound from the throat. If left untreated for a long time, it may result in eye diseases. This condition manifests as cataracts or closed eyelids that cannot open, with tears resembling paste, and over time leads to pus discharge, finally resulting in the eye becoming desiccated. Why does this happen? It is due to the downward movement of yang qi and the upward reversal of yin qi. The treatment should follow the principles of yin and yang as discussed in the Great Treatise: clear yang exits from the upper orifices, while turbid yin exits from the lower orifices; clear yang activates the pores, while turbid yin affects the five organs; clear yang fills the limbs, while turbid yin returns to the six bowels. Each should be returned to its origin, not reversed from its normal state; this is how it should be treated. One should prepare formulas to raise yang and lower yin, such as Poria Decoction to Drain Dampness or the formula with Cimicifuga and Gentian. These medicines are not solely for the eyes but also address the aforementioned symptoms. However, one should not delay treatment, as it may become dangerous; parents must be vigilant![4p]
Rituals of Filial Piety 【Yuan Dynasty, Zhang Congzheng】

         Inflammation of the Eyes

For young children with inflamed eyes that do not open for several days, this is caused by wind-heat. You can take Liangge San to clear the liver channel of excess wind-heat. Once the congestion is resolved, the eyes will open on their own.[5p]
Teething Problems

For children with teething issues and tooth decay, this is due to the decay of the gums. The lower teeth are associated with the Hand Yangming Large Intestine meridian, governed by dry metal, while the upper teeth relate to the Foot Yangming Stomach meridian, governed by moist earth. Both are linked to the intestines and stomach. This may be caused by accumulated heat within, or due to the ingestion of toxic substances such as silver powder or dainty beans, which harm the intestines and stomach, rendering dairy and food unable to counter the poison. The toxic vapors then travel along the meridians to the delicate gums and gaps between the teeth, creating harm. It can be treated with musk and jade thread. The wet nurse, before sleeping, should take a dose of Huanglian Detoxifying Decoction, and the dental issues will resolve naturally.

Remarkable and Effective Recipe 【Ming Dynasty, Fang Xian】

Gastrointestinal Worms

In children, the symptoms of gu (nutritional impairment caused by parasitic infestations) (hiding worms below) include drowsiness and irritability, a runny nose with foul-smelling discharge, sores on the teeth, and black blood in diarrhea. Worms affect the lower body, causing sores on the lower lip; when they affect the organs, sores appear on the upper lip. The "three worms" refer to roundworms, hookworms, and pinworms, of which there are nine types, with pinworms commonly affecting people. Pinworms result from consuming beef and drinking white liquor; if they interconnect, they can be fatal. When medication is taken to expel them, it is best for them to exit in a wrapped, complete form. If the infestation is interconnected, they should be removed promptly. Pinworms predominantly affect children, but adults can also be affected. This condition causes heart pain; if someone is irritable and has a bitter taste in their mouth during the Qing Dynasty, this is also related. Other types of diverse infestations can be detrimental, as everyone has worms in their stomachs; it is advisable to take the Nine Worm Pill to eliminate them.[6p]
Infant's Hundred Questions (Ming Dynasty, by Lu Bosi)

Thirsting Sickness

All instances of thirsting sickness are illnesses of the spleen and stomach, arising from the loss of bodily fluids. These conditions are often caused by severe illnesses or by vomiting and diarrhea, leading to the weakness of the spleen and stomach and the depletion of internal fluids. Furthermore, children's thirsting sickness is often worsened by incompetent doctors. When the sickness manifests as tidal fever, it indicates the spleen's deficiency and the presence of inner heat; thus, the treatment should focus on nourishing the mother organ while purging the affected organ for recovery.

For instance, if the tidal fever occurs at noon, it indicates heart deficiency and heat; since the liver is the mother of the heart, one should first nourish the liver, then purge the heart once the liver is strong, restoring balance and thus alleviating the tidal fever. Doctors who observe tidal fever mistakenly diagnose it as an issue of excess and recklessly use cooling laxatives like rhubarb and other such medicines. This aggressive purging only exacerbates the condition by further depleting bodily fluids, ultimately leading to thirsting sickness. There are also other related ailments where symptoms include intermittent attacks along with sensations of cold or heat, and firm painful sensations beneath the ribs.[7p]
The method to treat phthisis should gradually wear away; however, if one uses drastic purgatives like croton seeds or realgar, it can harm children because they easily fluctuate between deficiency and excess. If purged too much, it will deplete the gastric fluids, leading to gradual emaciation due to phthisis.

Children’s organs are delicate, and overeating can easily cause harm. If there is any irregularity in breastfeeding and dietary habits, it is rare not to cause phthisis, which leads to injury. Indulging in sweet, rich, sticky, cold, salty, or sour foods can obstruct the stomach and cause phthisis from accumulation. If the wet nurse maintains an inappropriate regimen or has emotional outbursts while nursing, the condition can be transmitted to the child, stemming from the mother’s ailments—this is beyond the capability of the patient’s family to rectify.

The symptoms of phthisis include a shiny and tense scalp, sparse and burnt hair, a shrunken face with dry nose, a craving for food with pale lips, dark and dull eyes, scratching the nose and eyebrows, a hunched back with a yellowish body, grinding teeth, thirst with sweating, whitish urine, acid diarrhea, abdominal bloating, intestinal rumbling, and a hot, sticky constitution. Those who have a strong desire for melons, salty, sour, charred food, rice, and earth, and crave drinking water all reflect the condition.

Phthisis is classified into five categories, as the disease pertains to the five organs.[8p]
Heart dysentery is also known as shock dysentery. The external symptoms include a strong body heat, red face, red lips, sores in the mouth and on the tongue, chest discomfort, dark and frequent urination, five hearts feeling hot, night sweats with thirst, and grinding of teeth due to nervousness.

Liver dysentery is also known as wind dysentery. The external symptoms include head shaking, eye rubbing, white membrane covering the eyes, watery eyes, a dry and frizzy head, blue veins, brain heat, restlessness with thirst, profuse sweating, and diarrhea with sores and rashes.

Kidney dysentery is also known as acute dysentery. The external symptoms include brain heat and muscle weakness, cold hands and feet, alternating cold and heat, loose stools with abdominal pain, dry mouth and nose, sores on gums, black nails, dark complexion, and numerous sores and scabs on the body.

Lung dysentery is also known as qi dysentery, and it is also referred to as dysentery (upper hidden, lower bugs).[9p]
External symptoms include coughing and wheezing with a strong fever and aversion to cold, skin eruptions, itchy nose and runny nose, sore throat, foul-smelling saliva, abdominal distension, and frequent diarrhea.

Spleen dampness (or food stagnation) is also known as milk dampness. Its external manifestations include yellowing of the body and face, a large abdomen with thin legs, vomiting and nausea, undigested food, acrid-smelling diarrhea, sleepiness with a slackened face, and a decrease in appetite with a craving for dirt.

For various forms of dampness, it is advisable to use large aloe pills, fat baby pills, hu huang lian pills, di huang pills, and raw and cooked di huang decoction, as these are essential medications. Additional remedies include Ji Sheng pills, ti gan san, zhi lian pills, five dampness good prescriptions, zhi sheng pills, tong shen pills, tian ma pills, di huang lung-clearing drink, hua (to conceal lower parasites) pills, ling zhi pills, xia chong pills, long dan pills, huang lian pills, xiang kao pills, mu xiang pills, he brown pills, huang qi soup with soft-shelled turtle blood decoction, oyster shell pills, hou po pills, and others, all of which should be used according to the specific symptoms for detailed treatment.[10p]
Kǒng Shāng (Kān)

Wǔ kàn chū chóng, wǔ zàng kàn yě. Qí yú yuē huái kàn, yuē jǐ kàn, yuē nǎo kàn, yuē gān kàn, yuē kàn kě, yuē kàn xiè, yuē kàn lì, yuē kàn zhǒng zhàng, yuē kàn láo, yuē wú gū kàn, yuē dīng xī, yuē bǔ lù, qí zhuàng fēi yī, bù kě bù cuō qí yào ér tiáo xī zhī.

Wǔ kàn chū chóng zhě, kàn shāng zhī yuán, suī qǐ yú rǔ pǐn bù tiáo, rán zàng fǔ tíng jī yǐ jiǔ, mò bù huà ér wéi chóng. Qí chóng huò rú sī fā, huò rú mǎ wěi, duō chū yú tóu xiàng fù bèi zhī jiān, huáng bái huò chì zhě kě zhì, qīng hēi zhě nán liáo yě.

Huái kàn zhě, shī rǔ fàn zǎo, shī ròu tài zǎo, huò shāng wèi tíng jù tián nì, huà wéi huái chóng, zhòu méi duō tái, ǒu tǔ qīng mò, fù zhōng zuò tòng, dù zhàng qīng jīn, chún kǒu zǐ hēi, tóu yáo chǐ yǎn shì yě. Cóng kǒu bí chū zhě nán zhì.[11p]
The condition of spinal gnawing manifests as worms eating the spine, with a body that is hot and emaciated, accumulating internal heat, causing thirst and diarrhea, and producing a sound like a drum when the back is tapped. The spine feels jagged, and there may be sores on all ten fingers, with a tendency to gnaw at the claws.

The condition of cerebral gnawing occurs when the fetus is poorly affected by wind and heat, and after being born, continues to be breastfed in an irregular manner. This results in a shiny and tense scalp, an abundance of scabs on the head, heat in the brain like fire, hair tangling like spikes, excessive sweating throughout the body, and swollen cheeks.

The condition of dry gnawing presents with emaciation and a lack of blood, a dry tongue, and the illness affects the heart. If the eyes are wide open without blinking, with little tearing, the illness is related to the liver; if there’s body heat with dry urine and cold hands and feet, it affects the kidneys; if skin feels scorched and dry while experiencing hard stools, it concerns the lungs; if there’s a spiritless sleep with dry chest and thirst, it relates to the spleen. Overall, these represent five types of gnawing.

The condition of gnawing thirst arises when there is internal wind with gnawing energy, compounded by the wet Nurse’s indulgence in strong tasting foods and alcohol, leading to stagnation and heat in the child’s heart and lungs. During the day, there is agitation, thirst, and refusal to take in breast milk, while at night they have a cessation of craving.

The condition of gnawing diarrhea features burned hair and pale lips, blue veins on the forehead, abdomen distension, and rumbling intestines, leading to excretion of undigested waste; do not use hot medications to stop it.

The condition of gnawing dysentery is related to the effects of wind, cold, heat, and humidity, or the imbalance of hot and cold, or the accumulation of retained food, preventing water and grains from coalescing and resulting in frequent expulsion of harmful substances.[12p]
Swelling from malnutrition is due to accumulated toxins and gases mingling, which causes abdominal swelling. This, in turn, gives rise to dampness affecting the spleen, leading to symptoms such as the head, face, hands, and feet feeling swollen and heavy. The treatment should focus on grinding the accumulation and regulating the qi.

For those suffering from malnutrition, there are recurring bouts of fever and heat, with restlessness in the heart and palms. The hands and feet may feel hot, with sores breaking out on the chest. Night sweats and bone heat may occur, along with a dry cough and emaciation. There may also be thirst followed by diarrhea, aversion to food, and a hard abdomen like stone, with a complexion resembling silver; such cases must not be treated.

In cases of unexplained malnutrition, there may be a hard nodular swelling at the back of the head and neck that can be felt to move; it is soft and not painful, sometimes containing worms resembling rice flour. If not dealt with, the worms disperse with heat, corrupting the internal organs and leading to abscesses and sores on the limbs, with pus and blood flowing, significant heat, and emaciation. The skull becomes prominent. Treatment involves needling and applying medicated plasters. Additionally, if a child's clothing is exposed under the eaves, becoming soiled by feathers from poisoned birds, worms may enter the skin and cause unexplained illness. After washing the clothes, they should be dried lightly over a fire.[13p]
If the hands and feet are exceedingly thin, the neck small with prominent bones, the buttocks slender and the body weak, the abdomen large with a protruding navel, crying with a sunken chest, or if there is a condition associated with malnutrition, this is known as "Ding Xi." If there are symptoms of fluctuating heat, separation of the skull bones, regurgitation of food with worms, thirst and vomiting, this is termed "bu lu." Both conditions arise from prolonged deficiency of the spleen and stomach, which cannot digest food and water, leading to diminished spirit and insufficiency of blood and qi, causing the muscles to wither and the kidney energy to be inadequate, which is further harmed by wind and cold, resulting in a faded physical form. There are also instances where the fetus is poisoned, resulting in insufficient blood in the organs. All these are various diseases arising from malnutrition, and when the illness reaches this point, it is indeed grave! It is advisable to use medicinals such as Fei Er Wan, Da Lu Hui Wan, Wu Gan Wan, Hu Huang Lian Wan, Zhi Sheng Wan, Fu Ling Wan, Tian Ma Wan, Di Huang Wan, Shi Quan Dan, Xiang Kuo Wan, He Wan Zi, Xiao Shi Wan, Bie Jia Wan, Xia Chong Wan, Ji Sheng Wan, and Huang Ji Jian Wan for early treatment, which would be ideal for recovery.

There are also chronic malnutritional conditions leading to excessive purging, where the intestines and stomach suffer from dampness, resembling the symptoms of fox-possessed cold and tooth erosion, sometimes referred to as "running horse." The teeth belong to the kidneys, and if there is kidney deficiency, it can be affected by heat pathogens, thus the malnutrition qi rushes to the upper burner, hence the term "running horse" as a metaphor. Initially, there is bad breath called "stinking breath"; then the teeth darken, leading to severe cases of gum rot and bleeding, termed "exposure." In the worst cases, all the teeth may fall out. For treatment, one should grind copper sulfate and fresh spider finely, add a small amount of musk, mix and apply to the teeth. If no spider is available, its shell may also be used.[14p]
Xu Lei (Emaciation)

Zhong Yang said: Emaciation occurs when the spleen and stomach are not in harmony, unable to digest food, leading to weakness of the skin and muscles. It can also arise after a major illness or after vomiting and diarrhea, when the spleen and stomach are still weak and unable to transform and absorb the energy from grains.

Those with cold symptoms experience frequent diarrhea, with pale blue lips; those with heat symptoms have a warm body and slightly yellow muscles. This describes cold and heat types of emaciation. For the cold type, use the Mu Xiang Wan (Saussurea Pill) as the primary treatment, but it should not be taken in the summer; if symptoms are present, it should be taken in moderation. For the heat type, the Hu Huang Lian (Coptis Pill) is indicated, but it should not be taken in the winter; if symptoms are present, it should also be taken in moderation.

For emaciation after contracting a cold, use the Zhu Ye Tang (Bamboo Leaf Decoction) as the primary treatment. Regularly consuming the Si Jun Zi Tang (Four Gentlemen Decoction), Yi Gong San (Extraordinary Merit Powder), or Shen Ling Bai Zhu San (Ginseng and Poria Powder) is also suitable. For long-term use, the Ju Lian Wan (Tangerine and Coptis Pill) can help with weight gain, in conjunction with the Fei Er Wan (Fat Child Pill).[15p]
Medical Accounts of the Right Transmission
(Ming - Yu Tuan)

Various Types of Malnutrition

The "Inner Canon" states: Eating too much rich food causes internal heat; eating too much sweet food leads to fullness in the abdomen. The cause of illness here is due to rich and sweet foods, hence it is termed malnutrition. As for infants in swaddling clothes and children aged four to five years, who are still nursing and have not yet gained full vitality, their digestive energy is not complete. If parents fail to balance their diet and instead indulge in the affection of overfeeding—allowing them to consume excess rich and sweet foods, as well as cold fruits and all manner of cooked and flavorful dishes, for breakfast and dinner—this gradually results in an accumulation of stagnation and firmness, leading to bodily heat and thinness, a pale yellow complexion, a distended abdomen with blue veins, intestinal pain, and diarrhea, thus manifesting the symptoms of malnutrition.

Qian Zhongyang stated: Children suffer from malnutrition often due to the aftermath of a major illness or after vomiting and diarrhea, caused by the medicinal treatment that damages the spleen and stomach, resulting in the loss of bodily fluids. This condition is truly the result of harm done by ignorant physicians. However, this view is only one facet and cannot be considered entirely accurate. Is it not the case that the major illness involving vomiting and diarrhea is often due to food? Since Zhongyang is regarded as the ancestor of pediatric medicine, could he be mistaken? His discussions on the symptoms and treatment of malnutrition are well-documented, and students should study them carefully.[16p]
If the condition (gan) is in the liver, it will cover the eyes; the treatment should nourish the liver, using Dixiao Pill as the primary remedy. If it is in the heart, the cheeks will be red, the body will feel hot; the treatment should nourish the heart, using Anshen Pill as the primary remedy. If it is in the spleen, the body will be yellow, the abdomen swollen, and there will be a craving for dirt; the treatment should nourish the spleen, using Yihuang Powder as the primary remedy. If it is in the lungs, there will be shortness of breath and mouth/nose sores; one should also nourish the spleen, again using Yihuang Powder as the primary remedy, as this pertains to nourishing the weaker organ; if it is in the kidneys, the person will be extremely thin with sores and scabs; the treatment should nourish the kidneys, using Dixiao Pill as the primary remedy. Bone-related conditions prefer lying on a cool surface; one should take the kidney-nourishing Dixiao Pill. If there are internal symptoms like swollen eyes, abdominal distension, irregular bowel movements, perhaps with frothy discharge that is greenish-white, leading to gradual weakness, this is a cold condition, and it would be appropriate to take the Muxiang Pill.[17p]
The external sore beneath the nose is red and rotten, and if rubbed, sores appear on the tip of the nose without scabbing, spreading around the eyes. One should treat these sores with herbs such as Lanxiang San and Baifen San. The method states: all sores arise from the internal organs, and by nourishing the mother organ, the child organ will naturally stabilize. For instance, when there is midday heat, it indicates deficiency heat in the heart. The liver is the mother of the heart; therefore, one should first nourish the liver, and only after the liver is strong can one drain the heart. If the heart receives the maternal qi, balance will be restored internally, and the midday heat will subside. All cases should follow this principle. Generally speaking, in treating sores, one must discern between hot and cold, as well as fat and thin: those who are newly affected tend to have fat heat sores, while those suffering for a long time tend to have thin cold sores. For cold, one should use Muxiang Wan, while for heat, one should use Huhuanglian Wan. When both hot and cold sores occur together, use something like Zhi Sheng Wan. However, one must consider the fragility of a child's internal organs; excessive purging will deplete fluids and lead to sore symptoms. Therefore, pediatricians should treat with a tender heart and adjust carefully, avoiding reckless actions that could interrupt future generations.[18p]

Medical Guidelines: Six Essentials (By Ming Dynasty Zhang Sanxi)

Kang Yan (Pediatric Eye Disease)

Children indulge in rich and sweet foods, are sensitive to cold and heat, and consume raw, oily, and fatty foods that harm the spleen. Sugary and hot items exacerbate fire within, leading to gradual accumulation and the onset of Kang disease. Symptoms include thirst and easy hunger, a good appetite but emaciation, hair standing upright with diarrhea, abdominal bloating, and dry nasal passages, accompanied by a wheezing sound. If left untreated for a long time, the spleen weakens while the liver strengthens, resulting in the liver fire scorching its channels, leading to vision issues and the formation of opacities. The eyelids may stick together and cannot open, and tears become thick. Over time, pus may flow due to the deficiency of the Middle and the failure of clear yang to ascend, while the overabundance of liver fire prevents the turbid yin from descending.

The treatment involves promoting clear and descending turbid: Begin with white atractylodes and ginseng to strengthen the spleen and stomach as the main ingredients. Then, use Bupleurum and bitter orange to assist the main remedy in regulating the spleen. Follow with the supporting herbs: together with poria, water plantain to drain dampness, and the wind-dispelling herbs such as Notopterygium, vitex, levisticum, chuanxiong, and mint to expel dampness effectively—this constitutes the rightful treatment.

Additionally, if children consume too much sweet food, they may suffer from bad breath, toothache, and swollen eyes, with a rapid pulse indicating stomach fire, treated by dispersing yellow powder. If the liver channel is excessively damp and hot, attacking the eyes with symptoms of eye discharge and abdominal bloating, the Jiu Wei Aloe Pill is a fine remedy. For those presenting with spleen deficiency, emaciation, and lack of appetite, intermittent use of Fatty Child Pill is suggested. For those inherently weak in yin with signs of internal fire, accompanied by symptoms of heart deficiency, use little of the Six Flavors Rehmannia Pill.[19p]
Various Types of Consumption

Consumption refers to ailments caused by excessive rich and sweet foods. Treatment should focus on regulating the spleen and stomach, dissipating accumulated heat and transforming parasites, as well as clearing heat, stopping diarrhea, and controlling dysentery, with primary reliance on Fat Child Pills and Consumption Cakes. These two remedies are effective regardless of whether the consumption is hot or cold. Generally, the disease of consumption arises from overeating, leading to accumulation in the spleen, which then transfers to other organs, resulting in the five types of consumption. What are the five types? They are related to the heart, liver, spleen, lungs, and kidneys.

If consumption affects the heart, there will be a red face, dry mouth, grinding of teeth, and sores in the mouth and tongue, with body heat and emaciation; treat it with Anshen Pills. If it affects the liver, there will be a bluish face, obstruction in vision, frequent tearing, prickling headache and stiff hair, with blue veins and heat in the brain leading to debility; treat it with Liver Tonifying Decoction. If it affects the spleen, there will be a yellow face and body heat, abdominal bloating, a desire to eat dirt, undigested food with sour-smelling diarrhea, lethargy, reduced appetite, and emaciation; treat it with Yihuang Powder. If it affects the lungs, there will be a pale face, cough, breathlessness, sores in the mouth and nose, throat discomfort, abdominal heat with aversion to cold, and clear nasal discharge; treat it with Lung Clearing Decoction. If it affects the kidneys, there will be a dark face, emaciated body with sores, body heat and frequent urination, cold hands and feet, and dry mouth and nose; treat it with Dihuang Pills.[20p]
Pediatric Essentials

Malnutrition

In children, all forms of malnutrition arise from the deficiency of the spleen and stomach following illness. This can occur from the excessive use of medicine, which harms their ability to digest milk and food, leading to a loss of bodily fluids and the emergence of false heat; or it may be caused by a wet nurse’s improper dietary habits and emotional stresses, which negatively affect the child. The manifestations of malnutrition differ according to the five organs, and must be identified accordingly. Despite the many symptoms, they all fundamentally relate to treatment of the five organs. For liver-related malnutrition, use Earth Huang Pills to nourish the kidneys. For heart-related malnutrition, use Calming Heart Pills for the heart and Yigong Powder to strengthen the spleen. For spleen-related malnutrition, use the Four Ingredient Fat Baby Pills and the Five Flavor Yigong Powder to enrich the earth element. For lung-related malnutrition, use Clear Lung Decoction for the lungs and Energizing Decoction to enhance the metal element. For brain-related malnutrition, also use Earth Huang Pills. For unjustly caused malnutrition, use Large Wood Plant Decoction and Toad Pills. For instances of sudden losses of energy and poor breastfeeding conditions, give Infant Pills or Large Aloe Vera Pills. For galloping malnutrition, apply Male Yellow Powder and administer Toad Pills. If symptoms like thirst, diarrhea, dysentery, swelling, or exhaustion occur, one should refer to specific prescriptions for treatment. In essence, malnutrition signifies dryness, resulting from the depletion of bodily fluids in the spleen and stomach. In children, this manifests as five types of malnutrition, while in adults it appears as five types of exhaustion, with the primary approach always focusing on balancing and nourishing the stomach energy.[21p]
Scurvy Injury

Generally, it is mainly caused by unregulated breastfeeding, injuring the spleen and qi, leading to the descent of primordial energy, or due to the emotions and diet of the wet nurse. If the urine resembles wash water, or if the stool is pale and watery, use the Four Flavored Fertilizer Pill; if there is stagnant accumulation that is yellow and black, use the Four Noble Ingredients Decoction with added Huáng Lián (Coptis) and Mù Xiāng (Saussurea); if the complexion is green for a long time without recovery, or if combined with diarrhea or abdominal pain, use the Six Noble Ingredients Decoction with added Mù Xiāng and Sháo Yào (Peony); if urination is difficult, the stool is brown, with yellowing and shedding of the skin, or sores below the nose, use the Gardenia and Poria Decoction; if there is little milk or appetite, a swollen chest and abdomen, and frequent bowel movements, use the Four Flavored Fertilizer Pill. Additionally, carefully examine the diet and emotions of the wet nurse.[22p]
Worms

The roundworm is one of the nine types of worms, measuring about five to six inches long. It arises from weakness of the organs and from eating rich, fatty foods. Its movements cause abdominal pain, alternating in intensity, often accompanied by drooling. If it penetrates the heart, it can be fatal; it is advised to use pills such as the "Junzi Wan" to expel them. Qian Zhongyang states that if there is drooling without heart pain, it indicates a cold stomach; if there is both drooling and heart pain, it is a worm-related pain, resembling epilepsy, but the eyes do not squint and the hands do not twitch. For this condition, it is prescribed to use "Anchong San." Tian Shi notes that with worm pain, one may cry, fidget, or be unable to sit or lay still, often pressing on the chest and abdomen, frequently crying out, with a complexion of green and yellow, lips partly white, eyes lacking luster, and drooling. If due to a cold stomach causing vomiting, one should take "Li Zhong Tang" with five roasted Sichuan peppers and half a liang of betel nut, and decoct with "Wu Mei Wan." It is said that when worms erode the upper part, there will be white spots on the upper lip; when they erode the lower part, there will be white spots on the lower lip. The various worms in the abdomen have their heads directed upwards when viewed from the front, and downwards when viewed from the back. To administer medicine, first use pig liver roasted in oil to release its aroma, allowing the child to smell it, which will make the worm's head turn upwards, facilitating the ingestion of medicine. If the Qi is weak and the worms are restless, one should simply tonify the spleen and stomach for tranquility. Master Danxi states that in winter, when expelling worms, it often indicates a deficiency of cold Qi in the stomach; the remedy is to use Qian's Bai Zhu San with two cloves of clove added.[23p]
Diagnosis and Treatment Principles
(Ming dynasty - Wang Kentang)

Consumption (Gan)

Consumption arises from an illness that damages the body, such as a cold that lasts five or six days and is sometimes accompanied by diarrhea. If treated excessively with cooling medicines, it can lead to spleen and stomach deficiency resulting in a decrease in bodily fluids, which in turn causes persistent thirst and generates internal heat. This internal heat consumes vitality, the muscles waste away, and other illnesses may interfere, leading to various symptoms that form the condition of consumption. Additionally, prolonged vomiting and diarrhea, or excessive improper treatment by physicians, can exacerbate the deficiency, causing agitation of bodily fluids and also leading to consumption.

In children, consumption often results from the inability to properly digest milk and food, causing accumulation in the belly. Variations in temperature can lead to persistent thirst, alongside symptoms resembling cough and wheezing, similar to tidal heat. If not treated early, it will inevitably lead to labor consumption. Due to the presence of accumulated conditions, children may refuse food, resulting in spleen and stomach deficiency and the production of heat, hence the yearning for drink. Excessive drinking will wash away the spleen and stomach's essence, leading to a loss of bodily fluids which cannot transform food and water. The pulse becomes deep and thin, indicating an inability to eat and drink, leading to further deficiency in the spleen and stomach, weakness in the limbs, and the emergence of various illnesses, ultimately resulting in consumption.

For children under twenty years of age, the illness is termed consumption; for those over twenty, it is termed tuberculosis. Both consumption and tuberculosis stem from deficiency of qi and blood, resulting from injury to the intestines and stomach, differing only in name. Why is this? Children have delicate organs; overconsumption easily harms them. Any disruption in diet from milk or food can seldom avoid leading to consumption. Consumption results from the imbalance in milk and food intake, excessive richness and lack of moderation.[24p]
Some infants may be deprived of milk, or they may be given porridge and rice too early, which exhausts their natural vitality and leads to the development of malnutrition; others, a few months later, may consume excessive milk and food, leading to overindulgence and malnutrition; some might indulge in sweet, fatty, sticky, or cold and salty foods, which can obstruct their digestive systems, causing malnutrition as a result; and if the wet nurse neglects proper care and the diet becomes irregular, influenced by their own emotions or exhaustion, and then they feed the child, malnutrition may be transmitted from mother to child due to the mother's condition. Is this not a case where the family cannot adjust to the illness? Malnutrition occurs when the spleen and stomach are affected, leading to a lack of bodily fluids. Some may develop it after vomiting or diarrhea from improper treatments that exhaust their bodily fluids; others may acquire it due to excessive heat and frequent diarrhea without restrictions, leading to dryness in the stomach; or because of a cold illness that has gone too far, causing thirst for water and then turning into heat, where heat has not dissipated and then is further affected by other pathogens; there are also cases of chronic cold and heat, with pain and hardness on the sides that cannot be gradually resolved, only to be harshly treated, resulting in bodily fluids being violently damaged. Is this not a case of doctors using harsh methods to treat the illness carelessly?

Liver malnutrition, also known as "wind liver" or "muscle malnutrition," manifests as white membranes covering the eyes, with muscle malnutrition presenting as diarrhea with blood and weight loss, the whites of the eyes appearing blue, accompanied by itchiness, head shaking and eye rubbing, sweating profusely, a hunched posture when sleeping, pale yellow complexion, sparse hair, blue veins and heat in the brain, and sores and eczema all over the body, with accumulations in the abdomen and frequent diarrheas. Over time, if not healed, the condition worsens, leading to severe weight loss, mucky discharge from the eyes, a left side of the forehead appearing blue, or slightly yellow in the whites of the eyes, with diarrhea mixed with water, or resembling the color of moss.

Heart malnutrition is also called "fright malnutrition."[25p]
Pale yellow face with a red complexion, robust body with heat, sores in the mouth, strong heat with variable diarrhea, red cheeks and yellow face, chest oppression and fullness, dry nose and restlessness of the heart, sores on the tongue and mouth, chronic dysentery not healing, frequent discharge of pus and blood, sometimes night sweats, or due to fright, red and cloudy urine, heat in all five hearts, grinding teeth and relaxing the tongue, fondness for cold drinks, and a tendency to lie on the ground.

Spleen dysentery, also known as food dysentery. Its symptoms include inability to digest food, frequent vomiting in stomach dysentery, many tendons in the abdomen, wheezing with coarse breathing, inadequate breast milk, bloating in the heart and abdomen with frequent crying and coughing, pale yellow complexion, protruding bones with rough hair, lean physique and weak strength, chest congestion, inability to digest food and water, constant dryness of mouth and nose, unhappiness, preference for darkness and aversion to light, disharmony in intestines and stomach, frequent sour and foul diarrhea, strong craving for cold foods, excessive drinking, both body and face becoming yellow, sparse hair forming tufts, large head and small neck, abdominal bloating with weak legs, occasional fermentation leading to diarrhea, emaciation and dull eyes, cool during the day and hot at night, loss of appetite for milk and food.

According to Qian, fatty dysentery is the same as spleen dysentery, where the body is thin and pale yellow, dry and with sores, with varying symptoms, many different forms. Here are some examples: eye discomfort or white membranes forming, lips and body dry, yellow or black, fondness for lying on cold ground, sometimes eating dirt, body with sores and scabs, diarrhea producing green, white, or yellow foam, changing colors of dysentery, abdominal fullness, sores in both ears and nose, sparse hair appearing like tufts, large head and thin neck, extreme emaciation with strong thirst for water, all these are its symptoms.

This describes the symptoms of spleen dysentery, often overlapping with other forms of dysentery, since dysentery stems from the spleen meridian as its root condition, it should naturally occur together.[26p]
Lung dysentery, also known as qi dysentery, is characterized by symptoms such as wheezing, sores in the mouth and nose, coughing, reversed qi, dry and withered skin, excessive mucus and weeping, throat discomfort, rubbing the nose and biting the nails, intense heat with aversion to cold, red and itchy lips, abdominal distension, decreasing milk and food intake, irregular bowel movements with frequent diarrhea, rice-like substances in the stool, millet-like growths on the skin, redness and ulceration under the nose, thin and withered hands and feet, a fishy smell in the mouth, and a pale right cheek.

Kidney dysentery, also known as acute dysentery or bone dysentery, presents symptoms such as extreme emaciation, presence of sores and scabs on the body, a preference for lying on cold surfaces, black teeth and nails, emaciated muscles and bones, sores on the gums, intermittent fevers, dryness of the mouth and nose, a brain feeling like it's on fire, cold feet, increased vomiting, reduced milk and food intake, frequent diarrhea, a relaxed lower body with an inability to control the anus, itchy and painful dysentery sores, sores inside and outside both ears, legs resembling crane knees, unjoined head sutures, inability to walk, delayed tooth emergence, and foul-smelling gaps in the teeth, potentially leading to conditions like running horse dysentery.[27p]
There is a child who has long suffered from kidney deficiency, with internal weakness and poor appetite, to the point that the cervical vertebrae are misaligned. The treatment should use Qian's Rehmannia Pill with additional remedies to expel parasites, as well as apply treatments to strengthen the muscles at the neck. If one does not recognize the symptoms and labels it as "five weakness," this is incorrect. Misalignment of the cervical vertebrae can occur in three conditions: 1) prolonged vomiting and diarrhea leading to weakness; 2) liver and gallbladder heat causing a red face and tongue that suddenly changes; 3) a febrile illness that fails to vent. All of these involve wind evil entering the liver, resulting in the relaxation of muscles and tendons. For those with vomiting and diarrhea, one should regulate the stomach’s qi. For liver heat, one should cool the liver according to severity, while also applying treatments to strengthen the muscles at the neck. However, misalignment due to febrile illness is difficult to treat.

Zhuang's Twenty-Four Indicators

First Indicator: purging of pus and blood, progressively losing weight, indicative of hot and cold deficiency.
Second Indicator: thin legs, a distended abdomen, protruding chest bones, craving for earthy and sour-salty foods, prolonged jaundice, occasional vomiting and diarrhea, abdominal pain, indicative of spleen deficiency.
Third Indicator: redness and sores beneath the nose, rubbing of the eyes accompanied by bloody diarrhea, indicative of lung deficiency. This is often due to consuming hot foods or injury to the heart and lungs from bad milk, exacerbated by coughs, and further aggravated by excessive intake of cold medicines, leading to internal heat and external cold, gradually causing confusion and frequent crying day and night.
Fourth Indicator: skin is thin and wrinkled, the face lacks color, the body itches and feels heated, causing irritability.
Fifth Indicator: sparse hair, sores on the nose, indicative of lung deficiency.
Sixth Indicator: sores on the head, sparse and burnt hair, indicative of liver deficiency.
Seventh Indicator: teeth that are yellow and reddish and inconsistent, indicative of kidney deficiency.[28p]
The eighth condition: dry and scorched hair, sores beneath the nose, is related to lung illness. The ninth condition: biting nails, hair forming tufts, heavy limbs, is associated with heart illness. The tenth condition: tendons growing on the abdomen, tooth decay, is considered bone illness. The eleventh condition: foul-smelling gums, pale face, lack of appetite, is known as spleen illness, also called mouth illness. The twelfth condition: vomiting and abdominal swelling, is stomach illness, also known as milk illness. The thirteenth condition: a desire to lie face down, excessive sleep akin to drunkenness, abdominal swelling and breathlessness, is due to the consumption of raw meat, indicating internal parasites and is referred to as heart-spleen illness. The fourteenth condition: dryness and pain in the nose, foul breath, fresh blood at the tooth roots, is liver-lung illness. The fifteenth condition: thin legs, a protruding belly, and blue veins on the abdomen, is spleen illness.[29p]
16th sign: Sores appear out of season, a preference for cold water, indicates heat dysentery.
17th sign: Grains on the skin, rice in feces, indicates cold spleen dysentery.
18th sign: Abdominal fullness and bloating, along with dry mouth, indicates heart and stomach dysentery.
19th sign: A desire for uncooked rice, flour, charcoal, and bricks, indicates spleen and stomach dysentery.
20th sign: Rubbing the nose and wiping the eyes, biting nails, and a thirst for water, indicates liver thirst dysentery.
21st sign: Alternating chills and heat, a desire to lie down and not get up, indicates bone heat dysentery.
22nd sign: A desire for water, eyes that won't open, indicates liver dysentery.
23rd sign: The body either hot or cold, constant thirst, indicates acute dysentery.
24th sign: Dark gums, lips that are sluggish to part, and red when opened, indicate heart dysentery with accumulated heat.
In children with internal dysentery, dry eyes, abdominal bloating, inconsistent stool color, or resembling watery sediment, gradually losing weight, this condition can be treated.[30p]
If there are sores and redness under the nose from rubbing, with pain and itching on the tip of the nose where scabs form, gradually causing discharge that runs to the ears, accompanied by red eyes, sparse hair, tight scalp, a large head with a thin neck, and a frail body, it can still be treated. If the lips and mouth are eroded, the gums display five colors or are completely black, with white sores under the tongue, holes in the palate, and persistent foul breath, gradually leading to decay of the gums, it can still be treated. If the lower body is open and occasionally reddens with unbearable itching, and there is irregular diarrhea, it can still be treated. If there are symptoms of malnutrition affecting the spine, with itchiness in all ten fingers leading to biting the nails, hair becoming tufted, the spine feeling like saw teeth, with occasional abdominal bloating and irregular diarrhea, prompt treatment will lead to recovery.

For children with liver malnutrition, if the eyes show blue veins, there is hardness under the left rib, frequent salivation, and blackness at the corners of the eyes, they cannot be treated. For heart malnutrition, if the child is frequently startled and cries, loves drinking water, prefers spicy food, has a pulse near the ears, and black spots on the tongue, it cannot be treated.[31p]
Spleen deficiency indicates a large abdomen, pale lips lacking blood color, a flat and full philtrum, excessive diarrhea, inability to digest food and water, a craving for dirt, dry skin, and exposed bones; such a condition is untreatable. Lung deficiency presents with coughing, shortness of breath, frequent white frothy diarrhea, skin lesions resembling corn, and a dark coloration; this condition is also untreatable. Kidney deficiency manifests as a craving for sour and salty foods, excessive thirst, milky urine, dark blue-black teeth, dryness in ears and brain, hunched shoulders, and emaciated bones; this is likewise untreatable.

Additionally, there are five signs of deficiency:

  1. Pain unnoticed at the base of the middle toe;
  2. Weakness in hands and feet, drooping and lax;
  3. Persistent illness with coldness throughout the body;
  4. Continuous output of green saliva and foam from the internal organs;
  5. Weakness in the tendons and muscles.

Conditions like these are all untreatable. When using medicine, careful examination is essential.

Deficiency refers to a chronic illness in children, often resulting from prolonged vomiting and diarrhea. Medical practitioners may mistakenly administer inappropriate drugs, causing imbalance between deficiency and excess in the child, leading to stomach weakness and loss of bodily fluids, internal heat, and muscle wastage. If one organ is weak, all will be affected. Symptoms include swollen eyelids, abdominal distention, inconsistent diarrhea, and gradual weight loss, making recovery unlikely. This indicates the presence of wind accumulation in the intestines and stomach, which should be treated by dispersing the wind and guiding it out, followed by nourishing the corresponding organ.[32p]
Zhu Zazheng

To counter heat, coolness is applied; to counter cold, warmth is applied; to balance both heat and cold, a combination of warming and cooling is utilized; this is the essence of it. Heat-related sickness often manifests externally, with symptoms such as red sores below the nose, wet itching sores on the head, restlessness of the five hearts, rough breathing when lifting the clothes, thirst for cold water, irritability while lying on the ground, a hot belly but cold feet, and intermittent tidal fever; all these are signs of heat-related illness. Cold-related sickness typically manifests internally, with unpredictable bowel movements, greenish-white diarrhea, weak limbs, swollen eyes, and a dark complexion. Additionally, there may be dryness and thirst while lying down, resembling heat, yet with an inability to intake food and constant diarrhea; this also indicates cold-related illness. If there is excessive diarrhea with pus and blood, leading to increasing weakness, it is termed a cold-heat illness. Generally, the cause of such illnesses is deficiency. Heat arises from internal deficiency of heat, while cold arises from internal deficiency of cold. When treating heat, one must not excessively cool; when treating cold, one must not sharply warm or swiftly replenish. Thus, Qian also states: children are easily affected by deficiency or excess. The spleen's deficiency cannot tolerate cold or heat; taking cold substances results in further cold, while taking warm substances leads to added heat; it is essential to recognize this to avoid errors. Is this not a fundamental principle for the young? The superior physician addresses this by dissolving accumulation, harmonizing the stomach, nourishing the blood, and regulating the qi, adhering to suitable medicines to support the patient, with light and simple diet for nourishment, ensuring harmony between the nourishing and protecting forces, allowing the organs to be naturally full. Any excess in this regard, and the gentleman cannot guarantee its success. The methods of treating accumulation must also be carefully weighed.[33p]
Accumulation is the root of consumption; it is called consumption when it becomes extreme due to accumulation. Those who have accumulation will always have a hot abdomen and cold feet, so one must carefully assess the condition of fullness and emptiness to treat them accordingly. If the accumulation leads to severe emptiness, then one should first support the stomach to ensure its energy is full, and then apply mildly purgative treatments. If accumulation is stronger than emptiness, then one should first use laxatives to promote a discharge, and urgently administer tonic medications to support the emptiness.

While it is appropriate to use laxatives to treat accumulation, one should not neglect remedies like cardamom, radish seeds, dried ginger, and herbs that dissolve accumulations. Pain in the sides or abdomen is also considered a form of accumulation within emptiness; it usually starts cold and later turns hot. Patients may experience coughing or wheezing due to drinking water, and there is a theory regarding accumulation causing tidal heat. Treatment should address both the cold and hot conditions and also include laxatives.

Considering these signs and symptoms, it is clear that the onset of the condition varies, and the methods of treatment are not uniform—thus one must exercise discretion in handling these cases! Generally, the illness of consumption arises from overeating and drinking, leading to accumulations within the spleen; if left untreated, these can affect the remaining organs and cause the five types of consumption diseases. If the spleen's issue is resolved, the other organs will also stabilize, but neglecting treatment for an extended period will inevitably lead to changes in the condition.

For spleen-related illnesses, one may use aloe pills, sandalwood-betel nut pills, or crystal elixirs and black rhinoceros pills, paying close attention to the balance of fullness and emptiness in treatment. For those with parasites, one may use the gentleman's pill or anti-parasitic decoction. For abdominal pain accompanied by vomiting clear fluids, indicating that the parasites are expelling downwards, one may frequently administer the two saint pills.[34p]
All types of malnutrition should appropriately use the formula "Wugan Baotong Wan" or "Cheng Wanying Wan" for regular consumption to resolve accumulation and treat malnutrition. Additionally, one should apply formulas to balance the corresponding organs: for calming the mind, use "Fushen Decoction"; for regulating the liver, use "Qiguai Decoction"; for regulating the spleen, use "Shenling Baizhu Powder"; for supplementing the lungs, use "Bulei Powder"; for nourishing the kidneys, use "Tiaoyuan Powder." If each treatment is suitable, the previous symptoms should not recur.

Accumulation is the mother of malnutrition; thus, if accumulation is not treated, it leads to malnutrition. Furthermore, if accumulation is not eliminated and remains while the organs are deficient, it severely worsens malnutrition. Generally, the malnutrition that children suffer from involves diarrhea at all times without the occurrence of wind symptoms. Only malnutrition-related diarrhea is named hot diarrhea, as the movement of the organs is limited, hence wind symptoms do not develop. Although there is no wind-induced diarrhea, it can transform into other symptoms: excessive thirst due to deficiency heat, agitation accompanied by diarrhea, abdominal swelling and shortness of breath are all indications of deficiency in malnutrition.

As the ancients said: when malnutrition is of deficient type, it should be supplemented, recognizing that malnutrition is a disease, and one should not further stimulate the organs. At the onset, it is called "malnutrition qi." When the abdomen is distended and tense, it is termed "malnutrition deficiency." Frequent diarrhea and dysentery are called "malnutrition accumulation." A feeling of five hearts being weak and troubled is called "malnutrition heat." Hair thinning and loss of vitality, a distended abdomen with visible veins, and a craving for unusual substances are called "malnutrition extreme" [indicating that the disease has reached a serious point]. Heat manifesting in fluctuations and the body being emaciated, with a lackluster complexion and pallor is termed "malnutrition fatigue."[35p]
The hands and feet are small, the neck is long and bony, the buttocks lack flesh, the abdomen is swollen and the navel protrudes, known as Dingxi. After eating, there is vomiting; the skull seems divided; there is thirst leading to drinking; worms come out of the mouth, called Bulu. All these are symptoms of malnutrition (gan). Additionally, due to excessive consumption of raw, cold, sweet, sticky, greasy foods, stagnation accumulates in the middle, failing to digest, leading to malnutrition over time.

To treat malnutrition, one must assess the severity of symptoms, regulate the organs, harmonize the middle, and ensure the three burners function well, allowing the stomach's energy to be warm and to accept food. Strengthening the spleen enhances digestion, causing the organs to naturally adjust, enabling the blood and qi to interact, and fortifying both muscle strength and bone strength, leading to clarity of spirit and vitality. This aids in the elimination of malnutrition and expulsion of worms, gradually leading to recovery.

However, if one attacks the internal organs with medicine, displacing the intestines and stomach, forcing out accumulated toxins and worms, this may be called medical treatment, yet it is not a genuine approach. An infant's organs are weak, making them prone to worms; weakness leads to stagnation, malnutrition, and fullness—what good is purging then? If one continues this cycle, the intestines and stomach become weak, resulting in malnutrition, turning the symptoms to weakness, making it impossible to save an innocent child.

If the symptoms are numerous and cannot be classified as a specific type of malnutrition, one should consult the various general treatment methods for malnutrition. If specific symptoms correspond to those of the five types of malnutrition, one should refer to the original treatment methods to differentiate between cold, heat, deficiency, and excess, using them accordingly. It is essential to understand this well to avoid errors.[36p]
Liver Illness

Liver illness is caused by improper diet, leading to heat in the liver. If the wet nurse fails to regulate temperature, indulges in flavors, or if the infant suffers from external wind and cold, combined with internal emotions of joy and anger, lingering evil qi can lead to the infant developing wind illness. The liver corresponds to the eyes; heat may accumulate in the upper diaphragm, causing phlegm and dampness, resulting in wind entering the eyes, causing redness, swelling, and obstructions, along with pus and tears that irritate the eyes, leading to pain, itchiness, and rubbing, which can result in dimness or even blindness, known as “eye illness.” External symptoms include shaking the head and rubbing the eyes, a white membrane covering the eyes, blue discoloration, excessive tears, a hot head with hair standing up, blue veins, a hot brain, itching on the nails, spasms in the tendons, dryness, thirst, excessive sweating, and diarrhea with sores. Qian recommends the Di Huang Pill for treatment, Yang advocates the Tian Ma Pill and cooked/raw Di Huang Decoction, and Zeng employs the Qi Gui Decoction for liver regulation.

Heart Illness

This is also caused by improper diet, resulting in heat in the heart. The blood and qi are unstable; improper nursing leads to stasis and internal heat, which has not been resolved, thus causing the heart to be disturbed and resulting in symptoms of anxiety and shock. External symptoms include a strong fever throughout the body, a red face and lips, oral ulcers, chest discomfort, red and scanty urine, heat in the palms and soles, night sweats with thirst, and a fragile, startled expression. Qian recommends the An Shen Pill for treatment. Xue uses the An Shen Pill for heart issues and Yi Gong Powder to supplement the spleen; Yang suggests the Fu Ling Pill and Qian's An Shen Pill; Zeng employs the Fu Shen Decoction for calming the heart.[37p]
Spleen Abscess

This occurs due to irregularities in milk and food intake, causing damage to the spleen and stomach. This may be caused by a wet nurse consuming excessively cold or rich food, or by overfeeding the infant, or by vomiting after milk consumption. Prolonged sleep after excessive milk intake may lead to milk lumps, and abdominal distension with lumps in the sides is also considered a milk abscess. External symptoms include a yellowish face, fever, a distended belly, weakness in the legs, vomiting and fullness, lethargy and crying, inability to digest food, and sour-smelling diarrhea. This condition is treated with Qian's Yi Huang San. Yang's method involves using Ling Zhi Wan in conjunction with Yi Huang San; Xue's approach uses Si Wei Fei Er Wan for abscess treatment and Wu Wei Yi Gong San for generating earth; Zeng's method adjusts the spleen with Shen Ling Bai Zhu San.

Lung Abscess

This arises from unregulated milk and food, causing obstruction and heat damaging the lungs. The lungs govern qi, and the nose is connected to the lungs. If the qi is unbalanced, wind and dampness can invade the skin and enter the blood vessels. Consequently, the area around the nose may develop red, itchy, damp sores, known as nasal abscesses. These sores are painless; where fluid flows can lead to ulceration, also referred to as an abscess (obscured upper and lower worms). External symptoms include coughing, wheezing, strong fever with chills, skin eruptions, nasal sores with discharge, sore throat, bloody saliva, abdominal distension with fine hair, and frequent diarrhea. Qian's treatment focuses on tonifying the spleen to generate the lungs, using Yi Huang San; Yang's method employs Qing Fei Yin Hua (obscured upper and lower worms) Wan, with Qian's E Jiao San also applied; Xue utilizes Qing Fei Yin for lung treatment, and Yi Qi Tang for generating gold; Zeng's approach uses Bu Fei San.[38p]
Shen Gan (Kidney Heat)

This condition arises from improper diet and the accumulation of heat in the internal organs. Sweet flavors enter the spleen and stimulate parasitic worms. When these worms are active, they invade the internal organs, leading to disturbances and discomfort in children's hearts. If the condition affects the mouth and gums, oral sores may bleed, and the teeth may turn purple-black; if it erodes the intestines and kidneys, there may be dysentery and anal ulcers, with湿 (dampness) causing itching and sores. If treatment is not initiated early, the essence and marrow can be depleted, making recovery difficult. These parasites (the upper ones hide and the lower ones burrow) are associated with dampness; they are often a result of prolonged diarrhea and damage from chronic illness to the intestines and stomach, resembling symptoms from dietary excess or cold damage leading to tooth decay, sometimes referred to metaphorically as 'running horse.'

Teeth relate to the kidneys, which govern weakness. If they are exposed to pathogenic heat, the heat energy drives upwards to the upper jiao (the area of the thorax), hence the metaphor of 'running horse.' Initially, foul breath is termed "stinking breath;" subsequently, teeth darken, known as "crumbling sand;" when severe, the gums rot, referred to as "decaying troughs;" if hot blood spurts out, it is termed "expressed leakage;" in extreme cases, all teeth may fall out, denoted as "rotten roots." Once the roots have decayed, even if one survives, the teeth do not regrow.

External symptoms include brain heat and muscle wasting, hands and feet feeling icy, alternating chills and fever, abdominal pain with slippery diarrhea, foul breath, gum sores, black nails, a sallow face, and numerous skin sores or scabies.

The Qian family's Di Huang Wan (Rehmannia Pill) is used to treat this condition; it should also include more Huang Qi (Astragalus) in Shen Mai San (Pulse-Strengthening Powder) to tonify the lungs. The Zeng family's Tiao Yuan San (Regulating Origin Powder) is also applied.[39p]
Hot and Cold Dysentery

The new form of dysentery is hot dysentery, characterized by a yellow complexion, flushed face, bone heat with night sweats, dry nose and foul breath, chapped lips with extreme thirst, irritability, and restlessness. If dysentery persists for a long time, it becomes cold dysentery, which presents with swollen eyes, abdominal distension, variable diarrhea with greasy stools, sometimes resembling oil drops, accompanied by thirst, yellowing, and emaciation. Hot dysentery tends to manifest externally, while cold dysentery primarily affects the internal. There are also cases where symptoms of hot and cold dysentery interact, neither new nor old, not purely external nor purely internal.[40p]
Innocent Illness

The child's face is pale, the hair is straight, and they often have a fever. Their appetite does not nourish their skin and flesh, and over time, this leads to death, which is called "innocent illness." It is said that in the heavens there is a bird named Innocent, which hides by day and roams by night, washing the clothes and bedding of children, exposing them overnight. This bird flies down from above, takes the clothes, and covers the child with them, causing the child to develop this illness.

For children with "innocent illness," there is a hard lump at the back of the head like a bullet. Pressing it causes it to rotate downwards. Whenever a child has this lump, like a pest under the tongue of livestock, if not removed promptly, it often leads to death. This lump initially forms soft and painless, containing a bug like rice flour; it grows larger with warmth. When it becomes large, it hardens, and the bug spreads with the blood and qi, causing blockages. The mother bug and offspring harm the organs, leading to sores on the skin and possibly purulent blood in the stool.

As a result, the child gradually becomes yellow and emaciated, with a large head and frail limbs, leading to premature death. Thus, children suffering from this disease have swollen bellies with purulent blood diarrhea, their hair and skin become dry and withered, and their bodies continue to weaken. Their intestines and stomach are already weak, experiencing diarrhea at all times, hence the name "innocent illness and diarrhea."[41p]
Mr. Wang of Han Dong said: When a child suffers from illness due to unwarranted reasons, it is said in ancient texts that there is a bird in the heavens named "Wugū." This bird, while drying a child’s clothing, passes urine on it if it is left out overnight, causing the child to cry and resulting in various ailments, leading to gradual yellowing and emaciation. This is not the case; rather, it is due to the harm caused by the eight evils. The eight evils are hunger, satiety, labor, fatigue, wind, fright, heat, and accumulation. They are known as the eight evils. Over time, this leads to gradual yellowing and emaciation, lack of nourishment despite eating, crying at night, a slight fever, excessive thirst, inability to sense hunger or satiety, and possibly developing sores or skin diseases.

In a song of eight verses by the Zhu family: The child's unwarranted energy often results from the mother's actions. If one can take care and be cautious, how could they witness such emaciation? Fright causes wind-related ailments, and warmth and cold create energy depletion. It is necessary to avoid sickly milk and not to overdress. Meals should not be rushed; speech should not be feared for its lateness. Discussing the eight prohibitions, the chest feels weak and heavy. The scalp is shiny and bare, with sparse hair. Liver stagnation affects the eyes, while spleen deficiency leads to yellowing in limbs. The entire body develops itchy rashes, and there are sores all over. Diarrhea and dysentery are relentless, with fluctuations in temperature. The embroidered ball is neglected, and how can a bamboo horse be ridden? By day, the eyes reveal a dull sheen, and drool hangs from the mouth. Toothed teeth must bite down, and raised hands need to push the brows. Each night they consume fruits, and each morning they eat dirt. The stomach harms the intestines, leading to bloating, and the lungs are filled, causing doubt in breath. Meals are unceasing, with sleep resembling intoxication.[42p]
Worms

If the condition of malnutrition persists and does not improve, there will be worms in the abdomen, the body will appear yellow and emaciated, and diarrhea will be continuous. It is advisable to take medicine to expel them, and as the malnutrition decreases, the symptoms will gradually diminish.

Roundworm Malnutrition

Jade Verse: Constant crying with phlegm and green roundworms, salivation creates cold pain that is hard to endure. Every meal of sweet foods and seasonal fruits leads to the growth of worms and deepens the illness. First, use Aristolochia powder and Aloe pills to expel the roundworms, then warm the spleen and stomach.

Dry Malnutrition

The body shows signs of heat, sometimes aversion to cold, the tongue is dry and the mouth parched, excessive sleep with night sweats, skin is dry, hair stands and becomes burnt, though there is much dairy and food, the muscles waste away, limbs feel weak, and there is a tendency to sleep in a daze. As time passes, the condition worsens, leading to further debilitation; this is the symptom.[43p]
Internal Canker

For children, if milk and food do not digest, with a feeling of emptiness and swelling in the heart and abdomen, eyes that are red and itchy, body heat and dry skin, digestive irregularities, diarrhea with five colors, gradually becoming emaciated, and worms eroding the rectum, it becomes more severe with time. The diarrhea does not cease, hence the term "internal canker." This is a cold syndrome and it is advisable to use Junzi pill.

External Canker

If the canker is external, it results in redness and ulceration beneath the nose, sores at the tip of the nose that do not scab, and sores developing around the ears. Now I will categorize and list "running horse canker," "oral canker," "nasal canker," "ocular canker," etc., as follows.

Running horse canker is the most severe form of canker, marked by the internal organs steaming with heat and attacking upwards, leading to a collapse akin to sand falling. The flesh at the edges of the teeth rots, the mouth emits a foul odor, there is a slight fever in the body, inability to eat, fresh blood oozing from the gaps between teeth, and the teeth feel shaky as if they are about to fall out, with the flesh rotting and falling away.

To treat it, first rinse the mouth with a mild saltwater solution, then administer Zijing powder mixed in, three times a day, to eliminate the worms at the edges of the teeth. If the condition is severe, apply Qiuchuang powder mixed in, then adjust with vermilion ointment and ox gall ointment combined with Tianzhu yellow powder, following the method of Master Mao. Alternatively, using Tianzhu yellow powder mixed with dihuang ointment is also effective, according to the method of Huiyan.

With such adjustments, the patient will be stable. If the condition does not improve and one to three teeth begin to fall out, the patient may not recover. Over time, the face will look gaunt, the cheeks will become hollow, and the patient may cease to live.[44p]
The treatment of initial symptoms with a retreat of wind-heat from the spleen and lungs should involve taking Betel Nut Powder in five to seven doses, followed by applying this medicine to the gums. Take a large jujube, remove the pit, and place a small amount of arsenic inside, then burn it to ash for application. Before sleeping, apply it to the gums several times for effectiveness.

Those experiencing this condition often suffer from qi deficiency due to cold, along with stagnation of retained food that does not pass, leading to accumulated warmth becoming heat. The deficiency heat rises and can be aggravated by consuming sweet, sour, salty, or greasy foods. Although the spleen enjoys sweetness, prolonged stagnation can trap heat that ascends to the mouth, causing teeth to become blackened and rotten, sometimes discharging clear blood. When blood accumulates, it may turn into pus that becomes foul and leads to dental erosion, even resulting in the cheeks being perforated. This follows with difficulties in eating dairy or other foods, a bright yet floating complexion, shortness of breath and heat, collectively termed "Running Horse Sore."

The method for treating this involves first eliminating the accumulated heat with a combination of Angelica Powder and Three-sided Powder, decocted with water, ginger, and jujubes for consumption. Next, administer Aloe Vera Pills, Jade Dew Decoction, and rinse with warm salt water. Alternatively, wash with a soft chicken feather dipped in salt water, then lightly dry, followed by applying Burnt Salt Powder, Inner Gold Powder, and Mithradate Powder.

If the condition does not improve over time, apply the treatment above and below the lips. If it progresses to a collapsing sand syndrome or leads to perforation of the cheeks, dislocated teeth, and exposed bone, along with reduced intake and wheezing, it will certainly lead to a dangerous state.[45p]
Mouth rot presents with symptoms such as itching and pain in the lips, blackened teeth, ulcers on the tongue, dry heat in the brain, red and rotten gums, swollen cheeks and toothaches, and foul breath due to the invasion of heat poison. This is a mild and slow form of the condition known as "running horse rot." The "Sacred Wisdom" describes it as excessive. Treatment should focus on clearing the stomach with formulas like Qingwei San and Ganlu Yin taken internally, while externally, one can use fried black myrobalan, green vitriol burnt red, and a small amount of human-centered white, applied with a bit of borneol to wipe the teeth, or adding betel nut powder to kill parasites is also acceptable.

For nasal rot, the symptoms include poor adjustment of dairy and food in children, causing stagnation in the upper body and allowing rot worms to erode the nose. Symptoms include redness and itching in the nose, strong fever with excessive crying, dry and brittle skin, emaciation, cough with difficulty breathing, irregular diarrhea, and sores at the nostrils and lips, hence it is called nasal rot.

The illness of damp rot often results from prolonged diarrhea and weak spleen and stomach, where worms in the intestines erode the five organs, causing distress and irritation. If the erosion occurs above, there will be ulcers in the mouth, nose, and gums; if below, the anus will be injured and rotten, making treatment difficult. This can also arise from long-term dysentery, internal heat causing excessive sleepiness, or a preference for sweet foods, which enables the worms to thrive and leads to this condition.[46p]
Children have a strong desire for sweet flavors, which often leads to the movement of various worms in the stomach and intestines, resulting in the erosion of the internal organs; this is akin to "upper concealment and lower worms." Generally, all five flavors enter the stomach, and their essence returns according to the tastes of the organs. The spleen and stomach are interrelated and are both associated with earth. Sweetness, being soft and moist, nourishes the spleen and stomach. When the spleen and stomach are nourished, the worms become active; when they are active, they cause erosion resulting in "gan" (a disease). Since the worms are stimulated by sweetness, it is named "gan." If the worms erode the lower part, sores will develop at the anus, and in severe cases, the child may die within days, necessitating urgent treatment.

If young children have irregular feeding habits, with improper combinations of hot and cold, they can harm their internal organs and lead to the "gan qi" (the essence of gan). When the spleen and stomach are weak, breastfeeding becomes ineffective, leading to a weak and cold large intestine, resulting in diarrhea. Chronic diarrhea can cause both the intestines and stomach to weaken, allowing dampness to invade, worms to move internally, and cause erosion of the lower parts; this is called "gan li shi" (gan with dampness).

Gan sores appear on the face and nose of children; they are neither itchy nor painful and often produce a discharge. Where the discharge flows, sores quickly form. These sores can also appear on other parts of the body, which is common in children and results from the clash of wind and dampness with the blood and qi; hence, they are not itchy or painful, which is why they are named "gan sores."[47p]
Five Types of Malnutrition

If there is vomiting, treat the vomiting; if there is diarrhea, treat the diarrhea; if there is accumulation, treat the accumulation; if there are worms, treat the worms. One should simply use the recipe for the Gathered Sage Pills, adjusting as needed; it has been repeatedly tested and proven effective.

Malnutrition

This refers to malnutrition characterized by symptoms such as scorching heat and bone fever, along with cough and night sweats. The medicinal formulas Tang's Turtle Shell Powder and Pig Stomach Pills are used to address these symptoms.

Malnutrition Accumulation

Symptoms include a face with a bluish-yellow tint, emaciation, abdominal swelling, erect hair, and body heat, along with slight abdominal pain. This condition arises from severe malnutrition leading to such symptoms. For treatment, first use the Harmonizing Qi Powder and the Awakening the Spleen Powder for two days to regulate. Then administer the Qingjindan to eliminate malnutrition accumulation, followed by the Harmonizing Qi and Awakening the Spleen Powders for nourishment. Regular use of the Baotong Pill will lead to recovery.
